By JORDAN GANTZ
Dr. Donald Benson,
Anesthesiologist-in Chief and

Hopkins. School of Medicine,
spoke on "A Western View of

Benson outlined a brief history

this subject, one which is
becoming increasingly
controversial in medical circles.
According to Benson,
acupuncture originated in China
about seven •thousand years ago,
although the exact location and
date are unknown. "The Chinese
philosophy of religion and life
has a lot to do with
acupuncture," stated Benson.
"They look at man as a
microcosmic image of the
universe and subject to identical

universal laws,"
According to Benson, Taoism
played an important part for the
Chinese in formulating their
theories about acupuncture.
"Taoism used a dual force to
explain many of nature's ways,
especially changes and
differences," he explained.
"These dual forces are the Yin
arid the Yang."
There are well over 1000 such
acupuncture points on the body.
The knowledge as to which
points when treated would lead
to successful results is, according
to Benson, "based on the
empiricism of seven thousand
years."
"The Chinese arrived at the
various points that would relieve
pain through what was basically a
hit and miss process. If some did
not work, they tried others."

skepticism about the actual value

further neurophysiological
research is necessary to place it in

perspective. His belief that
acupuncture treatment may be
helpful to atleast some patients

evident when he stated that
"acupuncture can change your
perception of pain."
